content: The "Civil Rights History Project Act of 2009" recognizes the importance of individuals standing up for their rights and beliefs, as demonstrated by the Civil Rights movement. The Act aims to preserve the first-hand memories and stories of those who participated in the movement. The "Civil Rights History Project Act of 2009" emphasizes the significance of collecting oral histories from individuals involved in the Civil Rights movement. The Library of Congress and the Smithsonian Institution are proposed as suitable repositories for preserving and sharing these firsthand accounts. This project aims to provide future generations with primary-source material to learn about the struggles and sacrifices made during this pivotal period in history. The Act aims to establish a federally funded project to collect video and audio recordings of personal histories from individuals involved in the American Civil Rights movement. The project will be jointly managed by the Library of Congress and the National Museum of African American History and Culture to preserve and share these firsthand accounts for future generations. The oral history project aims to survey and collect audio and video recordings of participants in the Civil Rights movement, along with personal histories and relevant materials. The collection will be cataloged and made available to the public through the Library of Congress and the National Museum of African American History and Culture. The Secretary will carry out duties through the Director of the National Museum of African American History and Culture. Agreements and partnerships with other entities may be used to carry out activities. Services of experts and consultants can be procured under specific regulations. The Librarian and the Secretary can utilize volunteers, reimburse travel expenses, make advances of money, and collect recordings for the Civil Rights movement. The term "Civil Rights movement" refers to the movement for racial equality in the US from 1954 to 1968. Private support for the Civil Rights History Project is encouraged through donations. The Librarian of Congress and the Secretary can accept donations to support activities under section 3. Donated funds will be dedicated solely to these activities. Appropriations of $500,000 for fiscal year 2010 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2011 through 2014 are authorized.
